titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the William Henricks Wiser and Charlotte Viall Wiser Papers

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday March 26, 2019 at 22:08

did.unittitle: William Henricks Wiser and Charlotte Viall Wiser Papers
did.abstract: William and Charlotte Wiser were Presbyterian missionaries in North India, appointed in 1915, and were active in the development of India Village Service, a demonstration project for the improvement of village life. These papers document the work of the Wisers in North India, particularly their involvement in rural reconstruction and their interest in Indian folklore.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: William Hendricks Wiser and Charlotte Viall Wiser Papers (RG 128), Special Collections, Yale Divinity School Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: William Henricks Wiser was born in Pennsylvania in 1890. He went to India under the auspices of the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. in 1915 after his graduation from the University of Chicago. Charlotte Viall joined him in India and they were married in Allahabad. William Wiser served on the staff of the Allahabad Agricultural Institute and as professor of rural sociology at the North India Theological College, Saharanpur. He also directed students in practical work in nearby villages. Charlotte Wiser also taught courses at the Allahabad Agricultural Institute.

Charlotte was born at Chicago, Illinois in 1892, and graduated from University of Chicago. She was sent as a Presbyterian missionary to India in 1916. She married William H. Wiser and they had three sons â€” Arthur, Alfred, and Edward. During their first term the Wisers were based in in Allahabad. During their second term(1925-1930), they worked in Mainpuri, and lived in the village of Karimpur, near Agra.
While on furlough in 1933, William Wiser completed a Ph.D. in rural social organization at Cornell University. Charlotte Wiser received a M.S. degree in nutrition from Cornell.

From 1945 to 1960 the Wisers were instrumental in the formation and direction of India Village Service, a demonstration project for the improvement of village life. William Wiser died in 1961 and Charlotte Wiser returned from India in 1970. Charlotte Wiser died in December 1981.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection provides valuable documentation of Presbyterian mission activity in North India. Much of of the correspondence, writings, diaries and printed material is related to rural India and the efforts of missionaries like the Wisers to improve the quality of village life.

As an avocation, William Wiser collected Indian folklore stories and songs. These stories and songs were told to native clerks who transcribed them in devanagari script. These transcripts were then copied in romanized Hindi, and finally translated into English.
Charlotte Wiser's active life as a woman missionary in rural India is well documented.
The first addendum (2010) includes material that Prof. Susan S. Wadley of Syracuse University used in her research regarding north India.

The second addendum (2104), which overlaps significantly with the early collection, provides additional documentation, particularly of the life and writings of Charlotte Wiser, and valuable early photographs and slides of India.
The series structure of the original collection has been changed to reflect the substantial additions.

list.item: II. Material related to India Village Service, 1934-1959
III. Material related to Indian folklore, n.d.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence is arranged chronologically. It includes letters from World Dominion Movement, International Missionary Council and Dorothy Parker, a missionary colleague (1951, 1952). Many of the letters describe village work during the time Dr. Wiser was director of India Village Service (1945-1960). Letter from Maurice L. Sill (1951) includes enclosure, "Colleagues in Action". Letters exchanged between Norvin Hein, Professor of Comparative Religion at Yale Divinity School, and Charlotte Wiser (1973, 1976) give information regarding the collection.

scopecontent.p: includes later creative writing course (Extension 122) with urgent reflection on purpose of writing ("having been out of the country for so long, it's hard to know what readers care about... it is a serious matter for us now. I must write to sell, if I can". A later piece makes reference to retirement cruise.
